commands.name: display.trigger.clear()
commands.description: This function clears the front‑panel trigger event detector.
commands.details: The trigger event detector remembers if an event has been detected since the last display.trigger.wait() call. This function clears the trigger event detector and discards the previous history of TRIG key presses.This attribute also clears the display.trigger.overrun attribute.

commands.name: display.trigger.EVENT_ID
commands.description: This constant is the event ID of the event generated when the front‑panel TRIG key is pressed.
commands.details: Set the stimulus of any trigger event detector to the value of this constant to have it respond to front-panel trigger key events.None

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The trigger event number

commands.name: display.trigger.overrun
commands.description: This attribute contains the event detector overrun status.
commands.details: Indicates if a trigger event was ignored because the event detector was already in the detected state when the TRIG button was pressed.Indicates the overrun state of the event detector built into the display.This attribute does not indicate whether an overrun occurred in any other part of the trigger model or in any other detector that is monitoring the event.

param_info.name: overrun
param_info.description: The trigger overrun state (true or false)

examples.description: Sets the variable overrun equal to the present state of the event detector built into the display.

commands.name: display.trigger.wait()
commands.description: This function waits for the TRIG key on the front panel to be pressed.
commands.details: If the trigger key was previously pressed and one or more trigger events were detected, this function returns immediately.After waiting for a trigger with this function, the event detector is automatically reset and rearmed. This is true regardless of the number of events detected.Use the display.trigger.clear() call to clear the trigger event detector.

param_info.name: triggered
param_info.description: true: Trigger was detected false: The operation timed out

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: Timeout in seconds

examples.description: Waits up to five seconds for the TRIG key to be pressed. If TRIG is pressed within five seconds, the output is true. If not, the output is false.

commands.name: display.waitkey()
commands.description: This function captures the key code value for the next front‑panel action.
commands.details: After you send this function, script execution pauses until a front‑panel action (for example, pressing a key or the navigation wheel, or turning the navigation wheel). After the action, the value of the key (or action) is returned.If the EXIT (LOCAL) key is pressed while this function is waiting for a front‑panel action, the script is not aborted.A typical use for this function is to prompt the user to press the EXIT (LOCAL) key to abort the script or press any other key to continue. For example, if the keyCode value 75 is returned (the EXIT (LOCAL) key was pressed), you can call the exit() function to abort the script.The table below lists the keyCode values for each front panel action.

param_info.name: keyCode
param_info.description: See Details for more information

commands.name: errorqueue.clear()
commands.description: This function clears all entries out of the error queue.

commands.name: errorqueue.count
commands.description: This attribute gets the number of entries in the error queue.

param_info.name: count
param_info.description: The number of entries in the error queue

examples.description: Returns the number of entries in the error queue. The output below indicates that there are four entries in the error queue:

commands.name: errorqueue.next()
commands.description: This function reads the oldest entry from the error queue and removes it from the queue.
commands.details: Entries are stored in a first-in, first-out (FIFO) queue. This function reads the oldest entry and removes it from the queue.Error codes and messages are listed in the Error summary list.If there are no entries in the queue, code 0, Queue is Empty, is returned.In an expanded system, each TSP‑Link enabled instrument is assigned a node number. The variable errorNode stores the node number where the error originated. The errorNode is always 1 on the 2604B/2614B/2634B.

param_info.name: errorCode
param_info.description: The error code number for the entry

param_info.name: message
param_info.description: The message that describes the error code

param_info.name: severity
param_info.description: The severity level (0, 10, 20, 30, or 40); see Details for more information

param_info.name: errorNode
param_info.description: The node number where the error originated

examples.description: Reads the oldest entry in the error queue. The output below indicates that the queue is empty. Output:

commands.name: eventlog.all()
commands.description: This function returns all entries from the event log as a single string and removes them from the event log.
commands.details: This function returns all events in the event log. Logged items are shown from oldest to newest. The response is a string that has the messages delimited with a new line character.This function also clears the event log.If there are no entries in the event log, this function returns the value nil.

param_info.name: logString
param_info.description: A listing of all event log entries

examples.description: Get and print all entries from the event log and remove the entries from the log. Output:

commands.name: eventlog.clear()
commands.description: This function clears the event log.
commands.details: This command removes all messages from the event log.

commands.name: eventlog.count
commands.description: This attribute returns the number of unread events in the event log.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The number of events in the event log

examples.description: Displays the present number of events in the instrument event log. Output looks similar to:

commands.name: eventlog.enable
commands.description: This attribute enables or disables the event log.
commands.details: When the event log is disabled (eventlog.DISABLE or 0), no new events are added to the event log. You can, however, read and remove existing events.When the event log is enabled, new events are logged.

param_info.name: status
param_info.description: The enable status of the event log: 1 or eventlog.ENABLE: Event log enable 0 or eventlog.DISABLE: Event log disable

examples.description: Displays the present status of the 2600B event log. Output:

commands.name: eventlog.next()
commands.description: This function returns the oldest unread event message from the event log and removes it from the event log.
commands.details: Returns the next entry from the event log and removes it from the log.If there are no entries in the event log, returns the value nil.

param_info.name: logString
param_info.description: The next log entry

examples.description: Get the oldest message in the event log and remove that entry from the log. Output:

commands.name: eventlog.overwritemethod
commands.description: This attribute controls how the event log processes events if the event log is full.
commands.details: When this attribute is set to eventlog.DISCARD_NEWEST, new entries are not logged.When this attribute is set to eventlog.DISCARD_OLDEST, the oldest entry is discarded when a new entry is added.

param_info.name: method
param_info.description: Set to one of the following values: 0 or eventlog.DISCARD_NEWEST: New entries are not logged 1 or eventlog.DISCARD_OLDEST: Old entries are deleted as new events are logged

examples.description: When the log is full, the event log ignores new entries.

commands.name: exit()
commands.description: This function stops a script that is presently running.
commands.details: Terminates script execution when called from a script that is being executed.This command does not wait for overlapped commands to complete before terminating script execution. If overlapped commands are required to finish, use the waitcomplete() function before calling exit().

commands.name: fileVar:close()
commands.description: This function closes the file that is represented by the fileVar variable.
commands.details: This command is equivalent to io.close(fileVar).Note that files are automatically closed when the file descriptors are garbage collected.

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The file descriptor variable to close

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;print("\n*** fileVar:close");do;myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1");myfile:close();end;myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "r");myfile:close();os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Opens file myfile.txt for writing. If no errors were found while opening, writes Removing file and closes the file.

commands.name: fileVar:flush()
commands.description: This function writes buffered data to a file.
commands.details: The fileVar:write() or io.write() functions buffer data, which may not be written immediately to the USB flash drive. Use fileVar:flush() to flush this data. Using this function removes the need to close a file after writing to it, allowing the file to be left open to write more data. Data may be lost if the file is not closed or flushed before a script ends. If there is going to be a time delay before more data is written to a file, and you want to keep the file open, flush the file after you write to it to prevent loss of data.

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The file descriptor variable to flush

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;errorqueue.clear();print("\n*** io.read");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1\n");myfile:flush();myfile:close();do;fileHandle = io.input(fileName);value = io.read("*a");print(value);end;fileHandle:close(); ;print(errorqueue.next());
examples.description: Writes data to a USB flash drive.

commands.name: fileVar:read()
commands.description: This function reads data from a file.
commands.details: The format parameters may be any of the following:"*n": Returns a number."*a": Returns the whole file, starting at the current position (returns an empty string if the current file position is at the end of the file)."*l": Returns the next line, skipping the end of line; returns nil if the current file position is at the end of file.n: Returns a string with up to n characters; returns an empty string if n is zero; returns nil if the current file position is at the end of file.If no format parameters are provided, the function performs as if the function is passed the value "*l".Any number of format parameters may be passed to this command, each corresponding to a returned data value.

param_info.name: data1
param_info.description: First data read from the file

param_info.name: data2
param_info.description: Second data read from the file

param_info.name: datan
param_info.description: Last data read from the file

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The descriptor of the file to be read

param_info.name: format1
param_info.description: A string or number indicating the first type of data to be read

param_info.name: format2
param_info.description: A string or number indicating the second type of data to be read

param_info.name: formatn
param_info.description: A string or number indicating the last type of data to be read
One or more entries (or values) separated by commas

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;print("fileVar:read");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1");myfile:close();do;myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "r");contents = myfile:read("*a");print(contents);end;myfile:close();os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Reads data from the input file.

commands.name: fileVar:seek()
commands.description: This function sets and gets the present position of a file.
commands.details: The whence parameters may be any of the following:"set": Beginning of file"cur": Current position"end": End of fileIf an error is encountered, it is logged to the error queue, and the command returns nil and the error string.

param_info.name: position
param_info.description: The new file position, measured in bytes from the beginning of the file

param_info.name: errorMsg
param_info.description: A string containing the error message

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The file descriptor variable

param_info.name: whence
param_info.description: A string indicating the base against which offset is applied; the default is "cur"

param_info.name: offset
param_info.description: The intended new position, measured in bytes from a base indicated by whence (default is 0)

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;errorqueue.clear(); ;print("\n*** fileVar:seek");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1");myfile:close();do;myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "r");position = myfile:seek("end", -1);print(position);end;myfile:close();os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Get the present position of a file.

commands.name: fileVar:write()
commands.description: This function writes data to a file.
commands.details: This function may buffer data until a flush (fileVar:flush() or io.flush()) or close (fileVar:close() or io.close()) operation is performed.

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The file descriptor variable

param_info.name: data
param_info.description: Write all data to the file

param_info.name: data1
param_info.description: The first data to write to the file

param_info.name: data2
param_info.description: The second data to write to the file

param_info.name: datan
param_info.description: The last data to write to the file
One or more entries (or values) separated by commas

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;errorqueue.clear(); ;print("\n*** fileVar:write");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");do;myfile:write("Line 1");end;myfile:close();os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Write data to a file.

commands.name: format.asciiprecision
commands.description: This attribute sets the precision (number of digits) for all numbers returned in the ASCII format.
commands.details: This attribute specifies the precision (number of digits) for numeric data printed with the print(), printbuffer(), and printnumber() functions. The format.asciiprecision attribute is only used with the ASCII format. The precision value must be a number from 0 to 16.Note that the precision is the number of significant digits printed. There is always one digit to the left of the decimal point; be sure to include this digit when setting the precision.

param_info.name: precision
param_info.description: A number representing the number of digits to be printed for numbers printed with the print(), printbuffer(), and printnumber() functions; must be a number between 1 and 16

examples.description: Output:

commands.name: format.byteorder
commands.description: This attribute sets the binary byte order for the data that is printed using the printnumber() and printbuffer() functions.
commands.details: This attribute selects the byte order in which data is written when you are printing data values with the printnumber() and printbuffer() functions. The byte order attribute is only used with the format.SREAL, format.REAL, format.REAL32, and format.REAL64 data formats.format.NORMAL, format.BIGENDIAN, and format.NETWORK select the same byte order. format.SWAPPED and format.LITTLEENDIAN select the same byte order. Selecting which to use is a matter of preference.Select the format.SWAPPED or format.LITTLEENDIAN byte order when sending data to a computer with a Microsoft Windows operating system.

param_info.name: order
param_info.description: Byte order value as follows: Most significant byte first: 0, format.NORMAL, format.NETWORK, or format.BIGENDIAN Least significant byte first: 1, format.SWAPPED or format.LITTLEENDIAN

examples.description: The output depends on the terminal program you use, but it looks something like:

commands.name: format.data
commands.description: This attribute sets the data format for data that is printed using the printnumber() and printbuffer() functions.
commands.details: The precision of numeric values can be controlled with the format.asciiprecision attribute. The byte order of format.SREAL, format.REAL, format.REAL32, and format.REAL64 can be selected with the format.byteorder attribute.REAL32 and SREAL select the same single precision format. REAL and REAL64 select the same double‑precision format. They are alternative identifiers. Selecting which to use is a matter of preference.The IEEE Std 754 binary formats use four bytes for single‑precision values and eight bytes for double‑precision values.When data is written with any of the binary formats, the response message starts with #0 and ends with a new line. When data is written with the ASCII format, elements are separated with a comma and space.

param_info.name: value
param_info.description: The format to use for data, set to one of the following values: ASCII format: 1 or format.ASCII Single‑precision IEEE Std 754 binary format: 2, format.SREAL, or format.REAL32 Double‑precision IEEE Std 754 binary format: 3, format.REAL, format.REAL64, or format.DREAL

examples.description: Output a number represented by x in ASCII using a precision of 10, then output the same number in binary using double‑precision format. Output:

commands.name: fs.chdir()
commands.description: This function sets the current working directory.
commands.details: The new working directory path may be absolute or relative to the current working directory.An error is logged to the error queue if the given path does not exist.

param_info.name: workingDirectory
param_info.description: Returned value containing the working path

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: A string indicating the new working directory path

examples.example: if fs.is_dir("/usb1/temp") == true then;  fs.chdir("/usb1/temp");  testPath = fs.cwd();  print(testPath);else;  testPath = fs.cwd();  print(testPath);end;
examples.description: Insert a USB flash drive into the front panel of the instrument. Verify that /usb1/temp is a directory and change it to be the current working directory. Set the variable for the current working directory to be testPath. The return should be: If /usb1/temp is not a directory, set the variable for the current working directory to be testPath. The return is:

commands.name: fs.cwd()
commands.description: This function returns the absolute path of the current working directory.

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The absolute path of the current working directory

examples.example: if fs.is_dir("/usb1/temp") == true then;  fs.chdir("/usb1/temp");  testPath = fs.cwd();  print(testPath);else;  testPath = fs.cwd();  print(testPath);end;
examples.description: Insert a USB flash drive into the front panel of the instrument. Verify that /usb1/temp is a directory and change it to be the current working directory. Set the variable for the current working directory to be testPath. The return should be: If /usb1/temp is not a directory, set the variable for the current working directory to be testPath. The return is:

commands.name: fs.is_dir()
commands.description: This function tests whether or not the specified path refers to a directory.
commands.details: The file system path may be absolute or relative to the current working system path.

param_info.name: status
param_info.description: Whether or not the given path is a directory (true or false)

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The path of the file system entry to test

examples.description: Because /usb1/ is always the root directory of an inserted flash drive, you can use this command to verify that USB flash drive is inserted.

commands.name: fs.is_file()
commands.description: Tests whether the specified path refers to a file (as opposed to a directory).
commands.details: The file system path may be absolute or relative to the current working system path.

param_info.name: status
param_info.description: true if the given path is a file; otherwise, false

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The path of the file system entry to test

examples.description: Insert a USB flash drive into the front panel of the instrument. Set rootDirectory to be the USB port. Check to see if rootDirectory is a file. Because rootDirectory was set up as a directory, the return is false.

commands.name: fs.mkdir()
commands.description: This function creates a directory at the specified path.
commands.details: The directory path may be absolute or relative to the current working directory.An error is logged to the error queue if the parent folder of the new directory does not exist, or if a file system entry already exists at the given path.

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The returned path of the new directory

param_info.name: newpath
param_info.description: Location (path) of where to create the new directory

examples.description: Insert a USB flash drive into the front panel of the instrument. Check to see if the temp directory exists. If it does not exist, create a directory named temp.

commands.name: fs.readdir()
commands.description: This function returns a list of the file system entries in the directory.
commands.details: The directory path may be absolute or relative to the current working directory.This command is nonrecursive. For example, entries in subfolders are not returned.An error is logged to the error queue if the given path does not exist or does not represent a directory.

param_info.name: files
param_info.description: A table containing the names of all the file system entries in the specified directory

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The directory path

examples.example: rootDirectory = "/usb1/";entries = fs.readdir(rootDirectory);count = table.getn(entries);print("Found a total of "..count.." files and directories");for i = 1, count do;   print(entries[i]);end;
examples.description: Insert a USB flash drive into the front panel of the instrument. Set rootDirectory to be the USB port. Set entries as the variable for the file system entries in rootDirectory. Return the number of files and directories in the directory.

commands.name: fs.rmdir()
commands.description: This function removes a directory from the file system.
commands.details: This path may be absolute or relative to the present working directory.An error is logged to the error queue if the given path does not exist or does not represent a directory. An error is also logged if the directory is not empty.

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The path of the directory to remove

examples.description: Insert a USB flash drive into the front panel of the instrument. Set rootDirectory to be the USB port. Set tempDirectoryName to be equivalent to temp. Check to see if tempDirectoryName exists. If it does not exist, create a directory named temp. Remove the directory.

commands.name: gettimezone()
commands.description: This function retrieves the local time zone.
commands.details: See settimezone() for additional details about the time zone format and a description of the fields.timeZone can be in either of the following formats:

param_info.name: timeZone
param_info.description: The local time zone of the instrument

examples.description: Reads the value of the local time zone.

commands.name: gm_isweep()
commands.description: This KIParlib factory script function performs a linear current sweep and calculates the transconductance (Gm) at each point.
commands.details: Output data includes transconductance values, reading buffer with measured voltages, reading buffer with measured voltages and currents.If all parameters are omitted when this function is called, this function is executed with the parameters set to the default values.The gm_isweep() function performs a linear current sweep, measuring voltage and current, and then calculating the transconductance (Gm) at each point using the central difference method. It can return an array of Gm values, a reading buffer with the measured voltages, and a reading buffer with the measured currents.

param_info.name: gm_array
param_info.description: A Lua table containing the calculated Gm values at each point

param_info.name: vbuf
param_info.description: A reading buffer containing the measured voltage at each point

param_info.name: ibuf
param_info.description: A reading buffer containing the measured current at each point

param_info.name: smu
param_info.description: Instrument channel (for example, smua refers to SMU channel A)

param_info.name: start_i
param_info.description: Starting current level of the sweep

param_info.name: stop_i
param_info.description: Ending current level of the sweep

param_info.name: points
param_info.description: Number of measurements between start_i and stop_i (must be ≥2)

usage: gm_array, vbuf, ibuf = gm_isweep(smu, start_i, stop_i, points)

examples.example: gm_array = gm_isweep(smua, 0, 0.01, 20); ; ;gm_array, vbuf = gm_isweep(smua, 0, 0.01, 20); ; ;gm_array, vbuf, ibuf = gm_isweep(smua, 0,;   0.01, 20);
examples.description: Source‑measure unit (SMU) A returns Gm values only.   SMU A returns Gm and reading buffer with measured voltages.   SMU A returns Gm and reading buffers with measured voltages and currents.

commands.name: gm_vsweep()
commands.description: This KIParlib factory script function performs a linear voltage sweep and calculates the transconductance (Gm) at each point.
commands.details: Output data includes transconductance values, reading buffer with measured currents, reading buffer with measured currents and voltages.The gm_vsweep() function performs a linear voltage sweep, measuring voltage and current, and then calculating the transconductance (Gm) at each point using the central difference method. It can return an array of Gm values, a reading buffer with the measured currents, and a reading buffer with the measured voltages.

param_info.name: gm_array
param_info.description: A Lua table containing the calculated Gm values at each point

param_info.name: ibuf
param_info.description: A reading buffer containing the measured current at each point

param_info.name: vbuf
param_info.description: A reading buffer containing the measured voltage at each point

param_info.name: smu
param_info.description: Instrument channel (for example, smua refers to SMU channel A)

param_info.name: start_v
param_info.description: Starting voltage level of the sweep

param_info.name: stop_v
param_info.description: Ending voltage level of the sweep

param_info.name: points
param_info.description: Number of measurements between start_v and stop_v (must be ≥ 2)

usage: gm_array, ibuf, vbuf = gm_vsweep(smu, start_v, stop_v, points)

examples.example: gm_array = gm_vsweep(smua, 0, 5, 20); ;gm_array, ibuf = gm_vsweep(smua, 0, 5, 20); ; ;gm_array, ibuf, vbuf = gm_vsweep(smua, 0, 5, 20);
examples.description: SMU A returns Gm values only.   SMU A returns Gm and reading buffer with measured currents.   SMU A returns Gm and reading buffers with measured currents and voltages.

commands.name: gpib.address
commands.description: This attribute contains the GPIB address.
commands.details: The address can be set to any address value from 1 to 30. However, the address must be unique in the system. It cannot conflict with an address that is assigned to another instrument or to the GPIB controller.A new GPIB address takes effect when the command to change it is processed. If there are response messages in the output queue when this command is processed, they must be read at the new address.If command messages are being queued (sent before this command has executed), the new settings may take effect in the middle of a subsequent command message, so use care when setting this attribute from the GPIB interface.You should allow sufficient time for the command to be processed before attempting to communicate with the instrument again.The reset() function does not affect the GPIB address.

param_info.name: address
param_info.description: The GPIB address of the instrument (1 to 30)

examples.description: Sets the GPIB address and reads the address. Output:

commands.name: i_leakage_measure()
commands.signature: i_leakage_measure(smuX, levelv, limiti, sourcedelay, measurei, measuredelay)
commands.description: This KIHighC factory script function performs a current leakage measurement after stepping the output voltage.
commands.details: This function causes the SMU to:When measuring leakage current:

param_info.name: imeas
param_info.description: The measured current

param_info.name: levelv
param_info.description: Voltage level to step to when this function is called

param_info.name: limiti
param_info.description: Current limit setting for the voltage step

param_info.name: sourcedelay
param_info.description: Delay to wait before lowering the current limit for measurement

param_info.name: measurei
param_info.description: Current limit (and measure range); the current limit is lower at this level and because high-capacitance mode is active, the measure range follows

param_info.name: measuredelay
param_info.description: Delay to wait after lowering the current limit before making the measurement

usage: imeas = i_leakage_measure(smuX, levelv, limiti, sourcedelay, measurei, measuredelay)

examples.description: Enable high-capacitance mode. Charge the capacitor at 5 V for 1 second set by delay(1).   The parameters passed on to the i_leakage_measure() function in this example are: The levels and delays depend on the value and type of capacitor used.

commands.name: i_leakage_threshold()
commands.signature: i_leakage_threshold(smuX, levelv, limiti, sourcedelay, measurei, measuredelay, threshold, timeout)
commands.description: This KIHighC factory script function measures the current and compares it to a threshold. This continues until either the measured current drops below the threshold or the timeout expires.
commands.details: This function causes the SMU to:When testing the leakage current threshold:

param_info.name: f
param_info.description: A Boolean flag; this flag is true when the current is below the threshold, false if threshold is not reached before timeout expires

param_info.name: levelv
param_info.description: Voltage level to step to when this function is called

param_info.name: limiti
param_info.description: Current limit setting for the voltage step

param_info.name: sourcedelay
param_info.description: Delay to wait before lowering the current limit for measurement

param_info.name: measurei
param_info.description: Current limit (and measure range); the current limit is lower at this level and because high-capacitance mode is active, the measure range follows

param_info.name: measuredelay
param_info.description: Delay before the first measurement after measure range is changed

param_info.name: threshold
param_info.description: The specified current that establishes the test limit

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: Amount of time (in seconds) to wait for the current to drop to threshold after all the delays have occurred

usage: f = i_leakage_threshold(smuX, levelv, limiti, sourcedelay, measurei, measuredelay, threshold, timeout)

examples.description: Enable high-capacitance mode. Charge the capacitor.    The parameters passed on to the i_threshold_measure() function in this example are: The levels and delays depend on the value and type of capacitor used. Sets pass = true if the current is measured below 1 µA in less than 1 second.

commands.name: InitiatePulseTest()
commands.description: This KIPulse factory script function initiates the pulse configuration assigned to tag.
commands.details: This function only initiates configured pulse trains assigned to a valid tag. Configure the pulse before initiating it using one of the ConfigurePulse* functions (refer to the Also see section).

param_info.name: f
param_info.description: A Boolean flag; this flag is true when the pulse was successfully configured, false when errors are encountered

param_info.name: msg
param_info.description: A string message; if the f flag is false, msg contains an error message; if it is true, msg contains a string that indicates successful configuration

param_info.name: tag
param_info.description: Numeric identifier of the pulse configuration to be initiated

examples.example: smua.reset(); ;smua.source.rangev = 5;smua.source.rangei = 1;smua.source.levelv = 0; ;smua.measure.rangev = 5;smua.measure.rangei = 1;smua.measure.nplc = 0.01;smua.measure.autozero = smua.AUTOZERO_ONCE; ;smua.nvbuffer1.clear();smua.nvbuffer1.appendmode = 1; ;smua.source.output = smua.OUTPUT_ON; ;f1, msg1 = ConfigPulseVMeasureI(smua, 0, 5, 1, 0.002, 0.2, 10, smua.nvbuffer1, 1); ;if f1 == true then;   f2, msg2 = InitiatePulseTest(1);   print("Initiate message:", msg2);else;   print("Config errors:", msg1);end;
examples.description: Configure channel A to generate a pulse train. If no errors are encountered, initiate the pulse train. Channel A pulses voltage from a bias level of 0 V to a pulse level of 5 V. The pulse level is present for 2 ms and the bias level for 200 ms, with a 1 A limit setting. A total of 10 pulses is generated, and the measurement data is stored in smua.nvbuffer1. This pulse train is assigned to tag = 1.

commands.name: InitiatePulseTestDual()
commands.description: This KIPulse factory script function initiates the pulse configuration assigned tag1 and tag2.
commands.details: The pulse trains associated with the indicated tags are generated simultaneously. This is useful when testing devices such as voltage regulators, where the input signal and output load must be applied to the instrument at the same time. When using this function, each tag1 pulse encapsulates each tag2 pulse in time. Specifically, the tag1 pulse transitions from its bias level to its pulse level before the tag2 pulse. Both the tag1 and tag2 pulses return to their respective bias levels at approximately the same time. Measurements for both pulse trains occur at the same time (see the waveform in the figure below).To provide this encapsulation, the following rules are enforced:

param_info.name: f
param_info.description: A Boolean flag; this flag is true when the pulse was successfully configured, false when errors were encountered

param_info.name: msg
param_info.description: A string message; if the f flag is false, msg contains an error message; if it is true, msg contains a string indicating successful configuration

param_info.name: tag1
param_info.description: Numeric identifier of the first pulse configuration to be initiated

param_info.name: tag2
param_info.description: Numeric identifier of the second pulse configuration to be initiated

examples.example: smua.reset(); ;smua.source.rangev = 5;smua.source.rangei = 1;smua.source.levelv = 0; ;smua.measure.rangev = 5;smua.measure.rangei = 1;smua.measure.nplc = 0.01;smua.measure.autozero = smua.AUTOZERO_ONCE; ;smua.nvbuffer1.clear();smua.nvbuffer1.appendmode = 1; ;smua.source.output = smua.OUTPUT_ON; ;smub.reset();smub.source.func = smub.OUTPUT_DCAMPS;smub.source.rangei = 1;smub.source.rangev = 5;smub.source.leveli = 0;smub.measure.rangei = 1;smub.measure.rangev = 5;smub.measure.nplc = 0.01;smub.measure.autozero = smub.AUTOZERO_ONCE;smub.nvbuffer1.clear();smub.nvbuffer1.appendmode = 1;smub.source.output = smub.OUTPUT_ON; ;f1, msg1 = ConfigPulseVMeasureI(smua, 0, 5, 1, 0.002, 0.2, 10, smua.nvbuffer1, 1);f2, msg2 = ConfigPulseIMeasureV(smub, 0,-1, 5, 0.001, 0.2, 10, smub.nvbuffer1, 2);if (f1 == true) and (f2 == true) then;   f3, msg3 = InitiatePulseTestDual(1, 2);   print("Initiate message:", msg3);else;   print("Config errors:", msg1, msg2);end;
examples.description: Set up channels A and B for pulse operation, configure pulse trains for each channel, and then initiate the pulse trains if no errors are encountered. Channel A pulses voltage from a bias level of 0 V to pulse level of 5 V. The pulse level is present for 2 ms, and the bias level for 200 ms with a 1 A limit setting. A total of 10 pulses is generated on channel A and the measurement data is stored in smua.nvbuffer1. This pulse train is assigned to tag = 1. Channel B pulses current from a bias level of 0 A to pulse level of 1 A. The pulse level is present for 1 ms, and the bias level for 200 ms with a 5 V limit setting. A total of 10 pulses is generated on channel B, and the measurement data is stored in smub.nvbuffer1. This pulse train is assigned to tag = 2.

commands.name: io.close()
commands.description: This function closes a file.
commands.details: If a file is not specified, the default output file closes.Only io.close(), used without specifying a parameter, can be accessed from a remote node.

param_info.name: file
param_info.description: The descriptor of the file to close

examples.example: testFile, testError = io.open("testfile.txt", "w");if nil == testError then;   testFile:write("This is my test file");   io.close(testFile);end;
examples.description: Opens file testfile.txt for writing. If no errors were found while opening, writes "This is my test file" and closes the file.

commands.name: io.flush()
commands.description: This function saves buffered data to a file.
commands.details: You must use the io.flush() or io.close() functions to write data to the file system.This function only flushes the default output file.Using this command removes the need to close a file after writing to it and allows it to be left open to write more data. Data may be lost if the file is not closed or flushed before an application ends. To prevent the loss of data if there is going to be a time delay before more data is written (and when you want to keep the file open and not close it), flush the file after writing to it.

commands.name: io.input()
commands.description: This function assigns a previously opened file, or opens a new file, as the default input file.
commands.details: The newfile path may be absolute or relative to the current working directory.When using this function from a remote TSP-Link® node, this command does not accept a file descriptor and does not return a value.If the function fails, an error message is returned.

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The descriptor of the input file or an error message (if the function fails)

param_info.name: newfile
param_info.description: A string representing the path of a file to open as the default input file, or the file descriptor of an open file to use as the default input file

commands.name: io.open()
commands.description: This function opens a file for later reference.
commands.details: The path to the file to open may be absolute or relative to the current working directory. If you successfully open the file, errorMsg is nil and fileVar has the descriptor used to access the file.If an error is encountered, the command returns nil for fileVar and an error string.

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The descriptor of the opened file

param_info.name: errorMsg
param_info.description: Indicates whether an error was encountered while processing the function

param_info.name: path
param_info.description: The path of the file to open

param_info.name: mode
param_info.description: A string representing the intended access mode ("r" = read, "w" = write, and "a" = append)

examples.example: testFile, testError = io.open("testfile.txt", "w");if testError == nil then;   testFile:write("This is my test file");   io.close(testFile);end;
examples.description: Opens file testfile.txt for writing. If no errors were found while opening, writes "This is my test file" and closes the file.

commands.name: io.output()
commands.description: This function assigns a previously opened file or opens a new file as the default output file.
commands.details: The path of the file to open may be absolute or relative to the current working directory.When accessed from a remote node using the TSP-Link network, this command does not accept a file descriptor parameter and does not return a value.If the function fails, an error message is returned.

param_info.name: fileVar
param_info.description: The descriptor of the output file or an error message (if the function fails)

param_info.name: newfile
param_info.description: A file descriptor to assign (or the path of a file to open) as the default output file

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;errorqueue.clear(); ;print("\n*** io.output");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1");myfile:close();do;fileHandle = io.output(fileName);print(fileHandle);end;io.close(fileHandle);print(fileHandle);os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Assign the file to be the default output file.

commands.name: io.read()
commands.description: This function reads data from the default input file.
commands.details: The format parameters may be any of the following:Any number of format parameters may be passed to this command, each corresponding to a returned data value.

param_info.name: data1
param_info.description: The data read from the file

param_info.name: data2
param_info.description: The data read from the file

param_info.name: dataN
param_info.description: The data read from the file; the number of return values matches the number of format values given

param_info.name: format1
param_info.description: A string or number indicating the type of data to be read

param_info.name: format2
param_info.description: A string or number indicating the type of data to be read

param_info.name: formatN
param_info.description: A string or number indicating the type of data to be read
One or more entries (or values) separated by commas

examples.description: Returns a string with up to N characters; returns an empty string if N is zero (0); returns nil if the present file position is at the end of file
Returns a string with up to N characters; returns an empty string if N is zero (0); returns nil if the present file position is at the end of file
Returns a string with up to N characters; returns an empty string if N is zero (0); returns nil if the present file position is at the end of file
Returns a string with up to N characters; returns an empty string if N is zero (0); returns nil if the present file position is at the end of file

commands.name: io.type()
commands.description: This function checks whether or not a given object is a file handle.
commands.details: Returns the string "file" if the object is an open file handle. If it is not an open file handle, nil is returned.

param_info.name: type
param_info.description: Indicates whether the object is an open file handle

param_info.name: obj
param_info.description: Object to check

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;errorqueue.clear(); ;print("\n*** io.type");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1");myfile:close();do;fileHandle = io.output(fileName);state = io.type(fileHandle);print(state);end;io.close(fileHandle);local state = io.type(fileHandle);print(state);os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Check whether or not fileName is a file handle.

commands.name: io.write()
commands.description: This function writes data to the default output file.
commands.details: All data parameters must be either strings or numbers.

param_info.name: data1
param_info.description: The data to be written

param_info.name: data2
param_info.description: The data to be written

param_info.name: dataN
param_info.description: The data to be written
One or more values separated by commas

examples.example: local fileName = "/usb1/myfile.txt"; ;if fs.is_file(fileName) then;	os.remove(fileName);	print("Removing file");else;	print("Nothing removed");end; ;errorqueue.clear(); ;print("\n*** io.write");myfile, myfile_err, myfile_errnum = io.open(fileName, "w");myfile:write("Line 1");myfile:close();do;fileHandle = io.output(fileName);io.write("Line 2");end;io.close(fileHandle);os.remove(fileName);
examples.description: Writes data to the default output file.

commands.name: lan.applysettings()
commands.description: This function re-initializes the LAN interface with new settings.
commands.details: Disconnects all existing LAN connections to the instrument and re-initializes the LAN with the present configuration settings.This function initiates a background operation. LAN configuration could be a lengthy operation. Although the function returns immediately, the LAN initialization continues to run in the background.Even though the LAN configuration settings may not have changed since the LAN was last connected, new settings may take effect due to the dynamic nature of dynamic host configuration protocol (DHCP) or dynamic link local addressing (DLLA) configuration.Re-initialization takes effect even if the configuration has not changed since the last time the instrument connected to the LAN.

commands.name: lan.autoconnect
commands.description: This attribute is used to enable or disable link monitoring.
commands.details: This attribute sets the LAN link monitoring and automatic connection state.When this is set to lan.ENABLE, all connections are closed if the link to the LAN is lost for more than the time specified by lan.linktimeout.Set this attribute to lan.ENABLE to automatically reset the LAN connection after the LAN link is established.

param_info.name: state
param_info.description: LAN link monitoring state: 1 or lan.ENABLE: Enables automatic link reconnection and monitoring 0 or lan.DISABLE: Disables automatic link reconnection and monitoring

examples.description: Enable LAN link monitoring.

commands.name: lan.config.dns.address[N]
commands.description: Configures DNS server IP addresses.
commands.details: This attribute is an array of Domain Name System (DNS) server addresses. These addresses take priority for DNS lookups and are consulted before any server addresses that are obtained using DHCP. This allows local DNS servers to be specified that take priority over DHCP‑configured global DNS servers.You can specify up to two addresses. The address specified by 1 is consulted first for DNS lookups. dnsAddress must be a string specifying the IP address of the DNS server in dotted decimal notation.Unused entries are returned as "0.0.0.0" when read. To disable an entry, set its value to "0.0.0.0" or the empty string "".Although only two addresses may be manually specified here, the instrument uses up to three DNS server addresses. If two are specified here, only one that is given by a DHCP server is used. If no entries are specified here, up to three addresses that are given by a DHCP server are used.

param_info.name: dnsAddress
param_info.description: DNS server IP address

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Entry index (1 or 2)

examples.description: Set the DNS address 1 to 164.109.48.173.

commands.name: lan.config.dns.domain
commands.description: Configures the dynamic DNS domain.
commands.details: This attribute holds the domain to request during dynamic DNS registration. Dynamic DNS registration works with DHCP to register the domain specified in this attribute with the DNS server.The length of the fully qualified host name (combined length of the domain and host name with separator characters) must be less than or equal to 255 characters. Although up to 255 characters are allowed, you must make sure the combined length is also no more than 255 characters.

param_info.name: domain
param_info.description: Dynamic DNS registration domain; use a string of 255 characters or less

examples.description: Outputs the present dynamic DNS domain. For example, if the domain is "Matrix", the response is:

commands.name: lan.config.dns.dynamic
commands.description: Enables or disables the dynamic DNS registration.
commands.details: Dynamic DNS registration works with DHCP to register the host name with the DNS server. The host name is specified in the lan.config.dns.hostname attribute.

param_info.name: state
param_info.description: The dynamic DNS registration state. It may be one of the following values: 1 or lan.ENABLE: Enabled 0 or lan.DISABLE: Disabled

examples.description: Outputs the dynamic registration state. If dynamic DNS registration is enabled, the response is:

commands.name: lan.config.dns.hostname
commands.description: This attribute defines the dynamic DNS host name.
commands.details: This attribute holds the host name to request during dynamic DNS registration. Dynamic DNS registration works with DHCP to register the host name specified in this attribute with the DNS server.The factory default value for hostName is "k‑<model number>‑<serial number>", where <model number> and <serial number> are replaced with the actual model number and serial number of the instrument (for example, "k‑2602B‑1234567"). Note that hyphens separate the characters of hostName. The length of the fully qualified host name (combined length of the domain and host name with separator characters) must be less than or equal to 255 characters. Although up to 63 characters can be entered here, you must make sure the combined length is no more than 255 characters.Setting this attribute to an empty string (in other words, setting this attribute to a string of length zero or a string that consists entirely of whitespace characters) reverts the host name to the factory default value.

param_info.name: hostName
param_info.description: The host name to use for dynamic DNS registration; the host name must: be a string of 63 characters or less start with a letter end with a letter or digit contain only letters, digits, and hyphens

examples.description: Outputs the present dynamic DNS host name.

commands.name: lan.config.dns.verify
commands.description: This attribute defines the DNS host name verification state.
commands.details: When this is enabled, the instrument performs DNS lookups to verify that the DNS host name matches the value specified by lan.config.dns.hostname.

param_info.name: state
param_info.description: DNS hostname verification state: 1 or lan.ENABLE: DNS host name verification enabled 0 or lan.DISABLE: DNS host name verification disabled

examples.description: Outputs the present DNS host name verification state. If it is enabled, the output is:

commands.name: lan.config.duplex
commands.description: This attribute defines the LAN duplex mode.
commands.details: This attribute does not indicate the actual setting currently in effect. Use the lan.status.duplex attribute to determine the present operating state of the LAN.

param_info.name: duplex
param_info.description: LAN duplex setting can be one of the following values: 1 or lan.FULL: Selects full-duplex operation 0 or lan.HALF: Selects half-duplex operation

examples.description: Set the LAN duplex mode to full.

commands.name: lan.config.gateway
commands.description: This attribute contains the LAN default gateway address.
commands.details: This attribute specifies the default gateway IP address to use when manual or DLLA configuration methods are used to configure the LAN. If DHCP is enabled, this setting is ignored.This attribute does not indicate the actual setting that is presently in effect. Use the lan.status.gateway attribute to determine the present operating state of the LAN.The IP address must be formatted in four groups of numbers, each separated by a decimal.

param_info.name: gatewayAddress
param_info.description: LAN default gateway address; must be a string specifying the default IP address of the gateway in dotted decimal notation

examples.description: Outputs the default gateway address. For example, you might see the output:

commands.name: lan.config.ipaddress
commands.description: This command specifies the LAN IP address.
commands.details: This command specifies the LAN IP address to use when the LAN is configured using the manual configuration method. This setting is ignored when DLLA or DHCP is used. This attribute does not indicate the actual setting that is presently in effect. Use the lan.status.ipaddress attribute to determine the present operating state of the LAN.

param_info.name: ipAddress
param_info.description: LAN IP address; must be a string specifying the IP address in dotted decimal notation

examples.description: Retrieves the presently set LAN IP address.

commands.name: lan.config.method
commands.description: This attribute contains the LAN settings configuration method.
commands.details: This attribute controls how the LAN IP address, subnet mask, default gateway address, and DNS server addresses are determined.When method is lan.AUTO, the instrument first attempts to configure the LAN settings using dynamic host configuration protocol (DHCP). If DHCP fails, it tries dynamic link local addressing (DLLA). If DLLA fails, it uses the manually specified settings.When method is lan.MANUAL, only the manually specified settings are used. Neither DHCP nor DLLA are attempted.

param_info.name: method
param_info.description: The method for configuring LAN settings; it can be one of the following values: 0 or lan.AUTO: Selects automatic sequencing of configuration methods 1 or lan.MANUAL: Use only manually specified configuration settings

examples.description: Outputs the present method. For example:

commands.name: lan.config.speed
commands.description: This attribute contains the LAN speed used when restarting in manual configuration mode.
commands.details: This attribute stores the speed that is used if the LAN is restarted for manual configuration operation.This attribute does not indicate the actual setting presently in effect. Use the lan.status.speed attribute to determine the present operating state of the LAN.The LAN speed is measured in megabits per second (Mbps).

param_info.name: speed
param_info.description: LAN speed setting in Mbps (10 or 100)

examples.description: Configure LAN speed for 100.

commands.name: lan.config.subnetmask
commands.description: This attribute contains the LAN subnet mask.
commands.details: This attribute specifies the LAN subnet mask that is used when the manual configuration method is used to configure the LAN. This setting is ignored when DLLA or DHCP is used.This attribute does not indicate the actual setting presently in effect. Use the lan.status.subnetmask attribute to determine the present operating state of the LAN.

param_info.name: mask
param_info.description: String that specifies the LAN subnet mask value in dotted decimal notation

examples.description: Outputs the LAN subnet mask, such as:

commands.name: lan.linktimeout
commands.description: This attribute contains the LAN link timeout period.
commands.details: You must enable the command lan.autoconnect before you can use this attribute.The timeout value represents the amount of time that passes before the instrument disconnects from the LAN due to the loss of the LAN link integrity.The LAN interface does not disconnect if the connection to the LAN is reestablished before the timeout value expires.If the LAN link integrity is not restored before the timeout value expires, the instrument begins to monitor for a new connection.

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: The LAN link monitor time-out period (in seconds)

examples.description: Outputs the present LAN link timeout setting.

commands.name: lan.lxidomain
commands.description: This attribute contains the LXI domain.
commands.details: This attribute sets the LXI domain number.All outgoing LXI packets are generated with this domain number. All inbound LXI packets are ignored unless they have this domain number.

param_info.name: domain
param_info.description: The LXI domain number (0 to 255)

examples.description: Displays the LXI domain.

commands.name: lan.nagle
commands.description: This attribute controls the state of the LAN Nagle algorithm.
commands.details: This attribute enables or disables the use of the LAN Nagle algorithm on transmission control protocol (TCP) connections.

param_info.name: state
param_info.description: The state of the Nagle algorithm: 1 or lan.ENABLE: Enable the LAN Nagle algorithm for TCP connections 0 or lan.DISABLE: Disable the Nagle algorithm for TCP connections

commands.name: lan.reset()
commands.description: This function resets the LAN interface.
commands.details: This function resets the LAN interface. It performs the commands lan.restoredefaults() and lan.applysettings(). It also resets the LAN password.

commands.name: lan.restoredefaults()
commands.description: This function resets LAN settings to default values.
commands.details: The settings that are restored are shown in the following table.This command is run when lan.reset() is sent.

examples.description: Restores the LAN defaults.

commands.name: lan.status.dns.address[N]
commands.description: This attribute contains the DNS server IP addresses.
commands.details: This attribute is an array of DNS server addresses. The instrument can use up to three addresses.Unused or disabled entries are returned as "0.0.0.0" when read. The dnsAddress returned is a string specifying the IP address of the DNS server in dotted decimal notation.You can only specify two addresses manually. However, the instrument uses up to three DNS server addresses. If two are specified, only the one given by a DHCP server is used. If no entries are specified, up to three address given by a DHCP server are used.The value of lan.status.dns.address[1] is referenced first for all DNS lookups. The values of lan.status.dns.address[2] and lan.status.dns.address[3] are referenced second and third, respectively.

param_info.name: dnsAddress
param_info.description: DNS server IP address

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Entry index (1, 2, or 3)

examples.description: Outputs DNS server address 1, for example:

commands.name: lan.status.dns.name
commands.description: This attribute contains the present DNS fully qualified host name.
commands.details: A fully qualified domain name (FQDN) specifies its exact location in the tree hierarchy of the Domain Name System (DNS).A FQDN is the complete domain name for a specific computer or host on the LAN. The FQDN consists of two parts: The host name and the domain name.If the DNS host name for an instrument is not found, this attribute stores the IP address in dotted decimal notation.

param_info.name: hostName
param_info.description: Fully qualified DNS host name that can be used to connect to the instrument

examples.description: Outputs the dynamic DNS host name.

commands.name: lan.status.duplex
commands.description: This attribute contains the duplex mode presently in use by the LAN interface.

param_info.name: duplex
param_info.description: LAN duplex setting can be one of the following values: 0 or lan.HALF: half-duplex operation 1 or lan.FULL: full-duplex operation

examples.description: Outputs the present LAN duplex mode, such as:

commands.name: lan.status.gateway
commands.description: This attribute contains the gateway address presently in use by the LAN interface.
commands.details: The value of gatewayAddress is a string that indicates the IP address of the gateway in dotted decimal notation.

param_info.name: gatewayAddress
param_info.description: LAN gateway address presently being used

examples.description: Outputs the gateway address, such as:

commands.name: lan.status.subnetmask
commands.description: This attribute contains the LAN subnet mask that is presently in use by the LAN interface.
commands.details: Use this attribute to determine the present operating state of the LAN. This attribute returns the present LAN subnet mask value if the LAN is manually configured, or when DLLA or DHCP is used.
