Current is measured at every step (point) in the sweep after a 1 ms source settling period.   The following table contains log values and corresponding source levels for the five‑point logarithmic sweep:

commands.name: timer.measure.t()
commands.description: This function measures the elapsed time since the timer was last reset.

param_info.name: time
param_info.description: The elapsed time in seconds (1 µs resolution)

examples.description: This example resets the timer and measures the time since the reset. Output: The output varies. The above output indicates that timer.measure.t() was executed 14.69077 seconds after timer.reset().

commands.name: timer.reset()
commands.description: This function resets the timer to zero (0) seconds.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].clear()
commands.description: This function clears the blender event detector and resets the overrun indicator of blender N.
commands.details: This command sets the blender event detector to the undetected state and resets the overrun indicator of the event detector.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The blender number (up to six)

examples.description: Clears the event detector for blender 2.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].EVENT_ID
commands.description: This constant contains the trigger blender event number.
commands.details: Set the stimulus of any trigger object to the value of this constant to have the trigger object respond to trigger events from this trigger blender.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: Trigger event number

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The blender number (up to six)

examples.description: Set the trigger stimulus of digital I/O trigger 1 to be controlled by the trigger blender 2 event.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].orenable
commands.description: This attribute selects whether the blender performs OR operations or AND operations.
commands.details: This command selects whether the blender waits for any one event (OR) or waits for all selected events (AND) before signaling an output event.

param_info.name: orenable
param_info.description: The type of operation: true: OR operation false: AND operation

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The blender number (up to six)

examples.description: Generate a trigger blender 1 event when a digital I/O trigger happens on line 3 or 5.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].overrun
commands.description: This attribute indicates whether or not an event was ignored because of the event detector state.
commands.details: Indicates if an event was ignored because the event detector was already in the detected state when the event occurred. This is an indication of the state of the event detector that is built into the event blender itself.This command does not indicate if an overrun occurred in any other part of the trigger model or in any other trigger object that is monitoring the event. It also is not an indication of an action overrun.

param_info.name: overrun
param_info.description: Trigger blender overrun state (true or false)

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The blender number (up to six)

examples.description: If an event was ignored, the output is true. If an event was not ignored, the output is false.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].reset()
commands.description: This function resets some of the trigger blender settings to their factory defaults.
commands.details: The trigger.blender[N].reset() function resets the following attributes to their factory defaults:It also clears trigger.blender[N].overrun.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger event blender (up to six)

examples.description: Resets the trigger blender 1 settings to factory defaults.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].stimulus[M]
commands.description: This attribute specifies the events that trigger the blender.
commands.details: There are four stimulus inputs that can each select a different event. The eventID parameter can be the event ID of any trigger event.Use zero to disable the blender input. The eventID parameter may be one of the existing trigger event IDs shown in the following table.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The event that triggers the blender action; see Details

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: An integer representing the trigger event blender (up to six)

param_info.name: M
param_info.description: An integer representing the stimulus index (1 to 4)

examples.description: Generate a trigger blender 1 event when a digital I/O trigger happens on line 3 or 5.

commands.name: trigger.blender[N].wait()
commands.description: This function waits for a blender trigger event to occur.
commands.details: This function waits for an event blender trigger event. If one or more trigger events were detected since the last time trigger.blender[N].wait() or trigger.blender[N].clear() was called, this function returns immediately.After detecting a trigger with this function, the event detector automatically resets and rearms. This is true regardless of the number of events detected.

param_info.name: triggered
param_info.description: Trigger detection indication for blender

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger blender (up to six) on which to wait

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: Maximum amount of time in seconds to wait for the trigger blender event

examples.description: Generate a trigger blender 1 event when a digital I/O trigger happens either on line 3 or 5. Wait three seconds while checking if trigger blender 1 event has occurred. If the blender trigger event has happened, then true is output. If the trigger event has not happened, then false is output after the timeout expires.

commands.name: trigger.clear()
commands.description: This function clears the command interface trigger event detector.
commands.details: The trigger event detector indicates if a trigger event has been detected since the last trigger.wait() call. trigger.clear() clears the trigger event detector and discards the history of command interface trigger events.

commands.name: trigger.EVENT_ID
commands.description: This constant contains the command interface trigger event number.
commands.details: You can set the stimulus of any trigger object to the value of this constant to have the trigger object respond to command interface trigger events.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The event ID for the command interface triggers

examples.description: Sets the trigger stimulus of trigger timer 1 to the command interface trigger event.

commands.name: trigger.generator[N].assert()
commands.description: This function generates a trigger event.
commands.details: Use this function to directly trigger events from the command interface or a script. For example, you can trigger a sweep while the instrument is under script control.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The generator number (1 or 2)

examples.description: Generates a trigger event on generator 2.

commands.name: trigger.generator[N].EVENT_ID
commands.description: This constant identifies the trigger event generated by the trigger event generator.
commands.details: This constant is an identification number that identifies events generated by this generator.To have another trigger object respond to trigger events generated by this generator, set the other object's stimulus attribute to the value of this constant.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The trigger event number

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The generator number (1 or 2)

examples.description: Uses a trigger event on generator 2 to be the stimulus for digital I/O trigger line 5.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].clear()
commands.description: This function clears the timer event detector and overrun indicator for the specified trigger timer number.
commands.details: This command sets the timer event detector to the undetected state and resets the overrun indicator.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Clears trigger timer 1.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].count
commands.description: This attribute sets the number of events to generate each time the timer generates a trigger event.
commands.details: If the count is set to a number greater than 1, the timer automatically starts the next trigger timer delay at the expiration of the previous delay.Set the count to zero (0) to cause the timer to generate trigger events indefinitely.If you use the trigger timer with a trigger model, make sure the count value is the same or more than any count values expected in the trigger model.

param_info.name: count
param_info.description: Number of times to repeat the trigger (0 to 1,048,575)

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Read trigger count for timer number 1.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].delay
commands.description: This attribute sets and reads the timer delay.
commands.details: Once the timer is enabled, each time the timer is triggered, it uses this delay period.Assigning a value to this attribute is equivalent to:This creates a delay list of one value.Reading this attribute returns the delay interval that is used the next time the timer is triggered.

param_info.name: interval
param_info.description: Delay interval in seconds (0.5 µs to 100 ks)

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Set the trigger timer 1 to delay for 50 µs.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].delaylist
commands.description: This attribute sets an array of timer intervals.
commands.details: Each time the timer is triggered after it is enabled, it uses the next delay period from the array. The default value is an array with one value of 10 µs.After all elements in the array have been used, the delays restart at the beginning of the list.If the array contains more than one element, the average of the delay intervals in the list must be ≥ 50 µs.

param_info.name: intervals
param_info.description: Table of delay intervals in seconds

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.example: trigger.timer[3].delaylist = {50e-6, 100e-6, 150e-6};DelayList = trigger.timer[3].delaylist;for x = 1, table.getn(DelayList) do;   print(DelayList[x]);end;
examples.description: Set a delay list on trigger timer 3 with three delays (50 µs, 100 µs, and 150 µs). Read the delay list on trigger timer 3. Output:

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].EVENT_ID
commands.description: This constant specifies the trigger timer event number.
commands.details: This constant is an identification number that identifies events generated by this timer.Set the stimulus of any trigger object to the value of this constant to have the trigger object respond to events from this timer.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The trigger event number

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Sets the trigger stimulus of trigger timer 1 to the TSP-Link trigger 2 event.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].overrun
commands.description: This attribute indicates if an event was ignored because of the event detector state.
commands.details: This command indicates if an event was ignored because the event detector was already in the detected state when the event occurred.This is an indication of the state of the event detector built into the timer itself. It does not indicate if an overrun occurred in any other part of the trigger model or in any other construct that is monitoring the delay completion event. It also is not an indication of a delay overrun.Delay overrun indications are provided in the status model.

param_info.name: overrun
param_info.description: Trigger overrun state (true or false)

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: If an event was ignored, the output is true. If the event was not ignored, the output is false.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].passthrough
commands.description: This attribute enables or disables the timer trigger pass‑through mode.
commands.details: When pass-through mode is enabled, triggers are passed through immediately and initiate the delay. When disabled, a trigger only initiates a delay.

param_info.name: passthrough
param_info.description: The state of pass-through mode; set to one of the following values: true: Enabled false: Disabled

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Enables pass‑through mode on trigger timer 1.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].reset()
commands.description: This function resets some of the trigger timer settings to their factory defaults.
commands.details: The trigger.timer[N].reset() function resets the following attributes to their factory defaults:It also clears trigger.timer[N].overrun.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Resets the attributes associated with timer 1 back to factory default values.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].stimulus
commands.description: This attribute specifies which event starts the timer.
commands.details: The eventID parameter may be one of the trigger event IDs shown in the following table.Set this attribute to the eventID of any trigger event to cause the timer to start when that event occurs.Set this attribute to zero (0) to disable event processing.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The event that triggers the timer delay

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

examples.description: Prints the event that starts a trigger 1 timer action.

commands.name: trigger.timer[N].wait()
commands.description: This function waits for a trigger.
commands.details: If one or more trigger events were detected since the last time trigger.timer[N].wait() or trigger.timer[N].clear() was called, this function returns immediately.After waiting for a trigger with this function, the event detector is automatically reset and rearmed. This is true regardless of the number of events detected.

param_info.name: triggered
param_info.description: Trigger detection indication

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: Trigger timer number (1 to 8)

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: Maximum amount of time in seconds to wait for the trigger

examples.description: Waits up to 10 s for a trigger on timer 3. If false is returned, no trigger was detected during the 10 s timeout. If true is returned, a trigger was detected.

commands.name: trigger.wait()
commands.description: This function waits for a command interface trigger event.
commands.details: This function waits up to timeout seconds for a trigger on the active command interface. A command interface trigger occurs when:If one or more of these trigger events were previously detected, this function returns immediately.After waiting for a trigger with this function, the event detector is automatically reset and rearmed. This is true regardless of the number of events detected.

param_info.name: triggered
param_info.description: true: A trigger was detected during the timeout period false: No triggers were detected during the timeout period

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: Maximum amount of time in seconds to wait for the trigger

examples.description: Waits up to 10 seconds for a trigger. If false is returned, no trigger was detected during the 10‑second timeout. If true is returned, a trigger was detected.

commands.name: tsplink.group
commands.description: This attribute contains the group number of a TSP‑Link node. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: To remove the node from all groups, set the attribute value to 0.When the node is turned off, the group number for that node changes to 0.The master node can be assigned to any group. You can also include other nodes in the group that includes the master. Note that any nodes that are set to 0 are automatically included in the group that contains the master node, regardless of the group that is assigned to the master node.

param_info.name: groupNumber
param_info.description: The group number of the TSP-Link node (0 to 64)

examples.description: Assign the instrument to TSP-Link group number 3.

related_commands: Using groups to manage nodes on a TSP-Link system

commands.name: tsplink.master
commands.description: This attribute reads the node number assigned to the master node. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: After doing a TSP-Link reset (tsplink.reset()), use this attribute to access the node number of the master in a set of instruments connected over TSP-Link.

param_info.name: masterNodeNumber
param_info.description: The node number of the master node

examples.description: Store the TSP-Link master node number in a variable called LinkMaster.

commands.name: tsplink.node
commands.description: This attribute defines the node number. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: This command sets the TSP‑Link node number and saves the value in nonvolatile memory.Changes to the node number do not take effect until tsplink.reset() from an earlier TSP‑Link instrument is executed on any node in the system.Each node connected to the TSP-Link system must be assigned a different node number.

param_info.name: nodeNumber
param_info.description: The node number of the instrument or enclosure (1 to 64 )

examples.description: Sets the TSP‑Link node for this instrument to number 3.

commands.name: tsplink.readbit()
commands.description: This function reads the state of a TSP-Link synchronization line. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: Returns a value of zero (0) if the line is low and 1 if the line is high.

param_info.name: data
param_info.description: The state of the synchronization line

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Assume line 3 is set high, and it is then read. Output:

commands.name: tsplink.readport()
commands.description: This function reads the TSP-Link trigger lines as a digital I/O port. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: The binary equivalent of the returned value indicates the input pattern on the I/O port. The least significant bit of the binary number corresponds to line 1 and the value of bit 3 corresponds to line 3. For example, a returned value of 2 has a binary equivalent of 010. This indicates that line 2 is high (1), and that the other two lines are low (0).

param_info.name: data
param_info.description: Numeric value that indicates which lines are set

examples.description: Reads state of all three TSP-Link lines. Assuming line 2 is set high, the output is: (binary 010) The format of the output may vary depending on the ASCII precision setting.

commands.name: tsplink.reset()
commands.description: This function initializes (resets) all nodes (instruments) in the TSP‑Link system. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: This function erases all information regarding other nodes connected on the TSP-Link system and regenerates the system configuration. This function must be called at least once before any remote nodes can be accessed. If the node number for any instrument is changed, the TSP-Link must be reset again.If expectedNodes is not given, this function generates an error if no other nodes are found on the TSP‑Link network.If nodesFound is less than expectedNodes, an error is generated. Note that the node on which the command is running is counted as a node. For example, giving an expected node count of 1 does not generate any errors, even if there are no other nodes on the TSP-Link network.Also returns the number of nodes found.

param_info.name: nodesFound
param_info.description: The number of nodes actually found on the system

param_info.name: expectedNodes
param_info.description: The number of nodes expected on the system (1 to 64)

examples.description: Perform a TSP-Link reset and indicate how many nodes are found. Sample output if two nodes are found:Nodes found = 2 Sample output if fewer nodes are found and if localnode.showerrors = 1:1219, TSP-Link found fewer nodes than expectedNodes found = 1

commands.name: tsplink.state
commands.description: This attribute describes the TSP‑Link online state. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: When the instrument power is first turned on, the state is offline. After tsplink.reset() is successful, the state is online.

param_info.name: state
param_info.description: TSP-Link state (online or offline)

examples.description: Read the state of the TSP‑Link system. If it is online, the output is:

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].assert()
commands.description: This function simulates the occurrence of the trigger and generates the corresponding event ID. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: The set pulse width determines how long the trigger is asserted.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Asserts trigger on trigger line 2.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].clear()
commands.description: This function clears the event detector for a LAN trigger. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: The trigger event detector enters the detected state when an event is detected. tsplink.trigger[N].clear() clears a trigger event detector, discards the history of the trigger line, and clears the tsplink.trigger[N].overrun attribute.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3) to clear

examples.description: Clears trigger event on synchronization line 2.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].EVENT_ID
commands.description: This constant identifies the number that is used for the trigger events. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: This number is used by the TSP-Link trigger line when it detects an input trigger.Set the stimulus of any trigger object to the value of this constant to have the trigger object respond to trigger events from this line.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The trigger event number

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Sets the trigger stimulus of trigger timer 1 to the TSP-Link trigger 2 event.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].mode
commands.description: This attribute defines the trigger operation and detection mode. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: This attribute controls the mode in which the trigger event detector and the output trigger generator operate on the given trigger line.The setting for the mode parameter can be one of the values shown in the following table.When programmed to any mode except tsplink.TRIG_BYPASS, the output state of the I/O line is controlled by the trigger logic and the user-specified output state of the line is ignored.When the trigger mode is set to tsplink.TRIG_RISING, the user‑specified output state of the line is examined. If the output state selected when the mode is changed is high, the actual mode that is used is tsplink.TRIG_RISINGA. If the output state selected when the mode is changed is low, the actual mode that is used is tsplink.TRIG_RISINGM.The mode parameter stores the trigger mode as a numeric value when the attribute is read.To control the line state, use the tsplink.TRIG_BYPASS mode with the tsplink.writebit() and the tsplink.writeport() commands.

param_info.name: mode
param_info.description: The trigger mode

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Sets the trigger mode for synchronization line 3 to tsplink.TRIG_RISINGM.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].overrun
commands.description: This attribute indicates if the event detector ignored an event while in the detected state. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: This command indicates whether an event has been ignored because the event detector was already in the detected state when the event occurred.This is an indication of the state of the event detector built into the synchronization line itself.It does not indicate if an overrun occurred in any other part of the trigger model, or in any other construct that is monitoring the event. It also is not an indication of an output trigger overrun. Output trigger overrun indications are provided in the status model.

param_info.name: overrun
param_info.description: Trigger overrun state

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: If an event was ignored, displays true; if an event was not ignored, displays false.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].pulsewidth
commands.description: This attribute sets the length of time that the trigger line is asserted for output triggers. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: Setting the pulse width to 0 (seconds) asserts the trigger indefinitely.

param_info.name: width
param_info.description: The pulse width (in seconds)

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Sets pulse width for trigger line 3 to 20 μs.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].release()
commands.description: This function releases a latched trigger on the given TSP‑Link trigger line. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: Releases a trigger that was asserted with an indefinite pulse width. It also releases a trigger that was latched in response to receiving a synchronous mode trigger.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Releases trigger line 3.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].reset()
commands.description: This function resets some of the TSP-Link trigger attributes to their factory defaults. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: The tsplink.trigger[N].reset() function resets the following attributes to their factory defaults:This also clears tsplink.trigger[N].overrun.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Resets TSP-Link trigger line 3 attributes back to factory default values.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].stimulus
commands.description: This attribute specifies the event that causes the synchronization line to assert a trigger. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: To disable automatic trigger assertion on the synchronization line, set this attribute to zero (0).Do not use this attribute when triggering under script control. Use tsplink.trigger[N].assert() instead.The eventID parameter may be one of the existing trigger event IDs shown in the following table.

param_info.name: eventID
param_info.description: The event identifier for the triggering event

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

examples.description: Prints the event that starts TSP-Link trigger line 3 action.

commands.name: tsplink.trigger[N].wait()
commands.description: This function waits for a trigger. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: This function waits up to the timeout value for an input trigger. If one or more trigger events were detected since the last time tsplink.trigger[N].wait() or tsplink.trigger[N].clear() was called, this function returns immediately.After waiting for a trigger with this function, the event detector is automatically reset and rearmed. This is true regardless of the number of events detected.

param_info.name: triggered
param_info.description: Trigger detection indication; set to one of the following values: true: A trigger is detected during the timeout period false: A trigger is not detected during the timeout period

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

param_info.name: timeout
param_info.description: The timeout value in seconds

examples.description: Waits up to 10 seconds for a trigger on TSP-Link® line 3. If false is returned, no trigger was detected during the 10-second timeout. If true is returned, a trigger was detected.

commands.name: tsplink.writebit()
commands.description: This function sets a TSP-Link trigger line high or low. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: Use tsplink.writebit() and tsplink.writeport() to control the output state of the trigger line when trigger operation is set to tsplink.TRIG_BYPASS.If the output line is write‑protected by the tsplink.writeprotect attribute, this command is ignored.The reset function does not affect the present states of the TSP-Link trigger lines.

param_info.name: N
param_info.description: The trigger line (1 to 3)

param_info.name: data
param_info.description: The value to write to the bit: Low: 0 High: 1

examples.description: Sets trigger line 3 low (0).

commands.name: tsplink.writeport()
commands.description: This function writes to all TSP‑Link synchronization lines. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: The binary representation of data indicates the output pattern that is written to the I/O port. For example, a data value of 2 has a binary equivalent of 010. Line 2 is set high (1), and the other two lines are set low (0).Write‑protected lines are not changed.Use the tsplink.writebit() and tsplink.writeport() commands to control the output state of the synchronization line when trigger operation is set to tsplink.TRIG_BYPASS.The reset() function does not affect the present states of the trigger lines.

param_info.name: data
param_info.description: Value to write to the port (0 to 7)

examples.description: Sets the synchronization lines 1 and 2 high (binary 011).

commands.name: tsplink.writeprotect
commands.description: This attribute contains the write‑protect mask that protects bits from changes by the tsplink.writebit() and tsplink.writeport() functions. This command is not available on the 2604B, 2614B, or 2634B.
commands.details: The binary equivalent of mask indicates the mask to be set for the TSP-Link trigger line. For example, a mask value of 5 has a binary equivalent of 101. This mask write‑protects TSP-Link trigger lines 1 and 3.

param_info.name: mask
param_info.description: An integer that specifies the value of the bit pattern for write‑protect; set bits to 1 to write‑protect the corresponding TSP-Link trigger line

examples.description: Write‑protects TSP-Link trigger lines 1 and 3.

commands.name: tspnet.clear()
commands.description: This function clears any pending output data from the instrument.
commands.details: This function clears any pending output data from the device. No data is returned to the caller and no data is processed.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

examples.description: Write data to a device, then print how much is available. Output: Clear data and print how much data is available again. Output:

commands.name: tspnet.connect()
commands.description: This function establishes a network connection with another LAN instrument or device through the LAN interface.
commands.details: This command connects a device to another device through the LAN interface. If the portNumber is 23, the interface uses the Telnet protocol and sets appropriate termination characters to communicate with the device.If a portNumber and initString are provided, it is assumed that the remote device is not TSP‑enabled. The 2600B does not perform any extra processing, prompt handling, error handling, or sending of commands. In addition, the tspnet.tsp.* commands cannot be used on devices that are not TSP‑enabled.If neither a portNumber nor an initString is provided, the remote device is assumed to be a Keithley Instruments TSP‑enabled device. Depending on the state of the tspnet.tsp.abortonconnect attribute, the 2600B sends an abort command to the remote device on connection. The 2600B also enables TSP prompts on the remote device and error management. The 2600B places remote errors from the TSP‑enabled device in its own error queue and prefaces these errors with Remote Error, followed by an error description. Do not manually change either the prompt functionality (localnode.prompts) or show errors by changing localnode.showerrors on the remote TSP-enabled device. If you do this, subsequent tspnet.tsp.* commands using the connection may fail.You can simultaneously connect to a maximum of 32 remote devices.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID to be used as a handle in all other tspnet function calls

param_info.name: ipAddress
param_info.description: IP address to which to connect in a string; accepts IP address or host name when trying to connect

param_info.name: portNumber
param_info.description: Port number (default 5025)

param_info.name: initString
param_info.description: Initialization string to send to ipAddress

examples.example: instrumentID = tspnet.connect("192.0.2.1");if instrumentID then;   -- Use instrumentID as needed here;   tspnet.disconnect(instrumentID);end;
examples.description: Connect to a TSP-enabled device.

commands.name: tspnet.disconnect()
commands.description: This function disconnects a specified TSP-Net session.
commands.details: This function disconnects the two devices by closing the connection. The connectionID is the session handle returned by tspnet.connect().For TSP-enabled devices, this aborts any remotely running commands or scripts.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

examples.description: Create a TSP‑Net session. Close the session.

commands.name: tspnet.execute()
commands.description: This function sends a command string to the remote device.
commands.details: This command sends a command string to the remote instrument. A termination is added to the command string when it is sent to the remote instrument (tspnet.termination()). You can also specify a format string, which causes the command to wait for a response from the remote instrument. The 2600B decodes the response message according to the format specified in the format string and returns the message as return values from the function (see tspnet.read() for format specifiers).When this command is sent to a TSP-enabled instrument, the 2600B suspends operation until a timeout error is generated or until the instrument responds. The TSP prompt from the remote instrument is read and discarded. The 2600B places any remotely generated errors into its error queue. When the optional format string is not specified, this command is equivalent to tspnet.write(), except that a termination is automatically added to the end of the command.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

param_info.name: commandString
param_info.description: The command to send to the remote device

param_info.name: value1
param_info.description: The first value decoded from the response message

param_info.name: value2
param_info.description: The second value decoded from the response message

param_info.name: valueN
param_info.description: The Nth value decoded from the response message; there is one return value for each format specifier in the format string
One or more values separated with commas

param_info.name: formatString
param_info.description: Format string for the output

examples.description: Command the remote device to run a script named runScript.

commands.name: tspnet.idn()
commands.description: This function retrieves the response of the remote device to *IDN?.
commands.details: This function retrieves the response of the remote device to *IDN?.

param_info.name: idnString
param_info.description: The returned *IDN? string

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

examples.description: Assume the instrument is at IP address 192.0.2.1. The output that is produced when you connect to the instrument and read the identification string may appear as:

commands.name: tspnet.read()
commands.description: This function reads data from a remote device.
commands.details: This command reads available data from the remote instrument and returns responses for the specified number of arguments.The format string can contain the following specifiers:A maximum of 10 format specifiers can be used for a maximum of 10 return values.If formatString is not provided, the command returns a string that contains the data until a new line is reached. If no data is available, the 2600B pauses operation until the requested data is available or until a timeout error is generated. Use tspnet.timeout to specify the timeout period.When the 2600B reads from a TSP-enabled remote instrument, the 2600B removes Test Script Processor (TSP®) prompts and places any errors it receives from the remote instrument into its own error queue. The 2600B prefaces errors from the remote device with "Remote Error," followed by the error number and error description.

param_info.name: value1
param_info.description: The first value decoded from the response message

param_info.name: value2
param_info.description: The second value decoded from the response message

param_info.name: valueN
param_info.description: The nth value decoded from the response message; there is one return value for each format specifier in the format string
One or more values separated with commas

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

param_info.name: formatString
param_info.description: Format string for the output, maximum of 10 specifiers

examples.description: Read a number (delimited by punctuation)
Read a number (delimited by punctuation)
Read a number (delimited by punctuation)
Read a number (delimited by punctuation)

commands.name: tspnet.readavailable()
commands.description: This function checks to see if data is available from the remote device.
commands.details: This command checks to see if any output data is available from the device. No data is read from the instrument. This allows TSP scripts to continue to run without waiting on a remote command to finish.

param_info.name: bytesAvailable
param_info.description: The number of bytes available to be read from the connection

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

examples.description: Send commands that create data. Wait for data to be available.

commands.name: tspnet.reset()
commands.description: This function disconnects all TSP-Net sessions.
commands.details: This command disconnects all remote instruments connected through TSP-Net. For TSP-enabled devices, this causes any commands or scripts running remotely to be terminated.

commands.name: tspnet.termination()
commands.description: This function sets the device line termination sequence.
commands.details: This function sets and gets the termination character sequence that is used to indicate the end of a line for a TSP-Net connection.Using the termSequence parameter sets the termination sequence. The present termination sequence is always returned.For the termSequence parameter, use the same values listed in the table above for type. There are four possible combinations, all of which are made up of line feeds (LF or 0x10) and carriage returns (CR or 0x13). For TSP-enabled devices, the default is tspnet.TERM_LF. For devices that are not TSP‑enabled, the default is tspnet.TERM_CRLF.

param_info.name: type
param_info.description: An enumerated value indicating the termination type: 1 or tspnet.TERM_LF 4 or tspnet.TERM_CR 2 or tspnet.TERM_CRLF 3 or tspnet.TERM_LFCR

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

param_info.name: termSequence
param_info.description: The termination sequence

examples.example: deviceID = tspnet.connect("192.0.2.1");if deviceID then;   tspnet.termination(deviceID, tspnet.TERM_LF);end;
examples.description: Sets termination type for IP address 192.0.2.1 to TERM_LF.

commands.name: tspnet.timeout
commands.description: This attribute sets the timeout value for the tspnet.connect(), tspnet.execute(), and tspnet.read() commands.
commands.details: This attribute sets the amount of time the tspnet.connect(), tspnet.execute(), and tspnet.read() commands wait for a response.The time is specified in seconds. The timeout may be specified to millisecond resolution but is only accurate to the nearest 10 ms.

param_info.name: value
param_info.description: The timeout duration in seconds (1 ms to 30.0 s)

examples.description: Sets the timeout duration to 2 s.

commands.name: tspnet.tsp.abort()
commands.description: This function causes the TSP-enabled instrument to stop executing any of the commands that were sent to it.
commands.details: This function is appropriate only for TSP-enabled instruments.Sends an abort command to the remote instrument.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: Integer value used as a handle for other tspnet commands

examples.description: Stops remote instrument execution on testConnection.

commands.name: tspnet.tsp.abortonconnect
commands.description: This attribute contains the setting for abort on connect to a TSP-enabled instrument.
commands.details: This setting determines if the instrument sends an abort message when it attempts to connect to a TSP‑enabled instrument using the tspnet.connect() function.When you send the abort command on an interface, it causes any other active interface on that instrument to close. If you do not send an abort command (or if tspnet.tsp.abortonconnect is set to 0) and another interface is active, connecting to a TSP‑enabled remote instrument results in a connection. However, the instrument does not respond to subsequent reads or executes because control of the instrument is not obtained until an abort command has been sent.

param_info.name: value
param_info.description: Enable: 1 Disable: 0

examples.description: Configure the instrument so that it does not send an abort command when connecting to a TSP‑enabled instrument.

commands.name: tspnet.tsp.rbtablecopy()
commands.description: This function copies a reading buffer synchronous table from a remote instrument to a TSP-enabled instrument.
commands.details: This function is only appropriate for TSP-enabled instruments.This function reads the data from a reading buffer on a remote instrument and returns an array of numbers or a string representing the data. The startIndex and endIndex parameters specify the portion of the reading buffer to read. If no index is specified, the entire buffer is copied. The function returns a table if the table is an array of numbers; otherwise a comma‑delimited string is returned.This command is limited to transferring 50,000 readings at a time.

param_info.name: table
param_info.description: A copy of the synchronous table or a string

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: Integer value used as a handle for other tspnet commands

param_info.name: name
param_info.description: The full name of the reading buffer name and synchronous table to copy

param_info.name: startIndex
param_info.description: Integer start value

param_info.name: endIndex
param_info.description: Integer end value

examples.description: Copy the specified readings table for buffer items 1 through 3, then display the first three readings. Example output:

commands.name: tspnet.tsp.runscript()
commands.description: This function loads and runs a script on a remote TSP-enabled instrument.
commands.details: This function is appropriate only for TSP-enabled instruments.This function downloads a script to a remote instrument and runs it. It automatically adds the appropriate loadscript and endscript commands around the script, captures any errors, and reads back any prompts. No additional substitutions are done on the text.The script is automatically loaded, compiled, and run.Any output from previous commands is discarded.This command does not wait for the script to complete.If you do not want the script to do anything immediately, make sure the script only defines functions for later use. Use the tspnet.execute() function to execute those functions later.If no name is specified, the script is loaded as the anonymous script.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: Integer value used as an identifier for other tspnet commands

param_info.name: name
param_info.description: The name that is assigned to the script

param_info.name: script
param_info.description: The body of the script as a string

examples.example: tspnet.tsp.runscript(myconnection, "mytest",;"print([[start]]) for d = 1, 10 do print([[work]]) end print([[end]])");
examples.description: Load and run a script entitled mytest on the TSP‑enabled instrument connected with myconnection.

commands.name: tspnet.write()
commands.description: This function writes a string to the remote instrument.
commands.details: The tspnet.write() function sends inputString to the remote instrument. It does not wait for command completion on the remote instrument.The 2600B sends inputString to the remote instrument exactly as indicated. The inputString must contain any necessary new lines, termination, or other syntax elements needed to complete properly.Because tspnet.write() does not process output from the remote instrument, do not send commands that generate too much output without processing the output. This command can stop executing if there is too much unprocessed output from previous commands.

param_info.name: connectionID
param_info.description: The connection ID returned from tspnet.connect()

param_info.name: inputString
param_info.description: The string to be written

examples.description: Commands the remote instrument to execute a command or script named runscript() on a remote device identified in the system as myID.

commands.name: userstring.add()
commands.description: This function adds a user-defined string to nonvolatile memory.
commands.details: This function associates the string value with the string name and stores this key-value pair in nonvolatile memory.Use the userstring.get() function to retrieve the value associated with the specified name.You can use the userstring functions to store custom, instrument-specific information in the instrument, such as department number, asset number, or manufacturing plant location.

param_info.name: name
param_info.description: The name of the string; the key of the key-value pair

param_info.name: value
param_info.description: The string to associate with name; the value of the key-value pair

examples.example: userstring.add("assetnumber", "236");userstring.add("product", "Widgets");userstring.add("contact", "John Doe");for name in userstring.catalog() do;   print(name .. " = " ..;      userstring.get(name));end;
examples.description: Stores user-defined strings in nonvolatile memory and recalls them from the instrument using a for loop. Example output:

commands.name: userstring.catalog()
commands.signature: for name in userstring.catalog() do body end
commands.description: This function creates an iterator for the user‑defined string catalog.
commands.details: The catalog provides access for user‑defined string pairs, allowing you to manipulate all the key-value pairs in nonvolatile memory. The entries are enumerated in no particular order.

param_info.name: name
param_info.description: The name of the string; the key of the key-value pair

param_info.name: body
param_info.description: Code to execute in the body of the for loop

usage: for name in userstring.catalog() do body end

examples.example: for name in userstring.catalog() do;   userstring.delete(name);end;
examples.description: Deletes all user‑defined strings in nonvolatile memory.

commands.name: userstring.delete()
commands.description: This function deletes a user-defined string from nonvolatile memory.
commands.details: This function deletes the string that is associated with name from nonvolatile memory.

param_info.name: name
param_info.description: The name (key) of the key-value pair of the user‑defined string to delete

examples.description: Deletes the user-defined strings associated with the assetnumber, product, and contact names.

commands.name: userstring.get()
commands.description: This function retrieves a user-defined string from nonvolatile memory.
commands.details: This function retrieves the string that is associated with name from nonvolatile memory.

param_info.name: value
param_info.description: The value of the user‑defined string key-value pair

param_info.name: name
param_info.description: The name (key) of the user‑defined string

examples.description: Create the user-defined string assetnumber, set to a value of 236. Read the value associated with the user-defined string named assetnumber. Store it in a variable called value, then print the variable value. Output:

commands.name: waitcomplete()
commands.description: This function waits for all previously started overlapped commands to complete.
commands.details: There are two types of instrument commands:The waitcomplete() command suspends the execution of commands until the instrument operations of all previous overlapped commands are finished. This command is not needed for sequential commands.A group number may only be specified when this node is the master node.If no group is specified, the local group is used.If zero (0) is specified for the group, this function waits for all nodes in the system.

param_info.name: group
param_info.description: Specifies which TSP-Link group on which to wait

examples.description: Waits for all nodes in the local group.

trigger_eventId.desc: Occurs when the source‑measure unit (SMU) transitions from the idle state to the arm layer of the trigger model
Occurs when the SMU moves from the arm layer to the trigger layer of the trigger model
Occurs when the SMU completes a source action
Occurs when the SMU completes a measurement action
Occurs when the SMU completes a pulse
Occurs when the SMU completes a sweep
Occurs when the SMU returns to the idle state
Occurs when an edge is detected on a digital I/O line
Occurs when an edge is detected on a TSP‑Link line
Occurs when the appropriate LXI trigger packet is received on LAN trigger object N
Occurs when the TRIG key on the front panel is pressed

Occurs when a *TRG command is received on the remote interface
GPIB only: Occurs when a GET bus command is received
USB only: Occurs when a USBTMC TRIGGER message is received
VXI-11 only: Occurs with the VXI-11 command device_trigger; reference the VXI-11 standard for additional details on the device trigger operation
Occurs after a collection of events is detected
Occurs when the trigger.generator[N].assert() function is executed
